content:
er 30, 2014
												If I had played this game when it first released 10 years ago, maybe I wouldn't have had such a big problem getting through this game. There are so many issues I had with the game that made the experience unpleasant, and a chore to get through.The guns are crap, in my opinion. Every single one of them. Most of them have pretty crappy accuracy, do little damage, and even point blank range with the shotgun takes a few shots to kill almost everything. The only gun worth anything was the sniper rifle, but only when prone. Otherwise, good luck with the broad side of that barn.The AI is stupid. They were shooting me with pinpoint accuracy through a wall at one point. Through a WALL. What the hell is up with this?Random guys with RPGs that are sometimes near impossible to spot can nearly one shot you if you're not paying attention.Your movement speed is horrid. You pretty much move as fast as a snail, and the sprinting is only a small fraction faster. Some of these levels are HUGE, and if you can't find any sort of vehicle, or the game doesn't give you one, well, god help you.This game is HARD as Hell. In the later levels, there are so many baddies in each swarm, some extremely powerful with way too much health, several of them at the same time, that I don't think its likely to be possible without cheating. I'm not a hardcore gamer, and I don't like this level of difficulty. I was playing on Normal...not even one of the harder difficulties, but I still couldn't do it.I didn't really find the story all that interesting. For me, it was just kind of there, behind the swarms and swarms of enemies.To me, the game just feels unbalanced, unpolished, even broken in some ways.This game had a few redeeming qualities thoughSome of the levels are pretty open, which allow for multiple approaches to getting past or through the enemies.Each level was unique and for the most part well-executed. Some areas are huge. The indoor level layout was pretty linear but this wasn't a problem for me because I grew up playing linear games like this.Actually, I think that's about it, off the top of my head. I didn't absolutely hate this game but I did not enjoy my experience with it. Unless you're a hardcore gamer who loves challenge, I would pass this up and try the other games in this series instead, or if you got the entire collection really cheap like I did, just don't bother with this one and start with Far Cry 2. This game is just too hard.5/10Meh

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2014
												Project Far Cry, also known as Far Cry is the original title in a franchise which has been successful for a decade now. Its setting has evolved a great deal since its inception. I'm not sure if Ubisoft was aware of what they were creating back in 2004 when Far Cry was released but I believe it's safe to assume most gamers have had a fair amount of enjoyment from the series.Far Cry was set on the world's most tropical island with crystal clear waters and a bright, vibrant, lush green bushes and rainforests. The setting of this game really is something you would dream of and is quite interesting in this respect - the environment is beautiful.As this game was released along-side to id software's Doom 3, Far Cry claimed via marketing to be so much better in every way. Unfortunately Far Cry was heavily over-rated by the media of the day and provides little to cater for new technologies and physics at its time. Doom 3 may have had serious hardware problems in its day but it has aged gracefully and the same cannot be said for Far Cry. I actually found Far Cry loves to randomly crash with critical errors, so naturally my judgement is that Far Cry was never completed - which might be the reason for my gripes with this game.I loved the weaponry - however limited, but especially the machine gun - for such a limited time of which I had. I enjoyed the method of mission delivery and how missions are carried out and the games general mechanics. The game does however feature broken physics, a disinteresting and mediocre story and really bad AI.As for the physics, it was quite simple that I expect not to be shot inside of a building from the outside with bullets and I would expect to never kill people outside in that situation - but honestly, it seems there's a first for everything. The story and protagonist were quite bad but I won't spoil any - I actually found more interest in the companion unlocked late in the game. The bad AI, well I wouldn't say the AI themselves are bad because I saw them perform some interesting things including team leaders giving their forces hand gestures - I'll admit that surprised me. What I mean is that the enemies can take you out from miles away with a rocket and there's nothing you can do about this - but when you get a rocket launcher you don't have the same accuracy. It seems there's some serious aimbot action happening here and I disapprove.My only other gripe is related to the realism of the tropical island setting - where the story progresses to include monsters and mutants and some seriously lame elements. Aside from this they basically have one-hit kills and take a lot of ammunition to take down so the difficulty fluctuates significantly and most people will give up on this game.To be fair I didn't use all the games mechanics, I didn't learn where enemies are exactly, so there's definitely a way through this game with ease but not without experience. I suppose I never used these features due to the control setup, and I just shifted the controls to my liking.Overall, I believe this game is highly over-rated and those calling this a classic are only doing it for nostalgia. It's a great game on the outside, nice and fun, but once you begin progressing you'll realise that it's not an amazing game with huge technological advances such to what everybody of the time were fed by the media, but it's nothing more than incomplete and broken.I'm glad its sequel was an improvement in every way, really.

y 25, 2014
												In some ways this is a neat game, It has smart gameplay mechanics and challenging enemy AI (a lot like the marines in Half Life). It is really more a predecessor to Crysis than Far Cry 2 which is almost in a different genre than FC1.However, I found this game to be more frustrating than entertaining. At first I had a lot of fun because I could use different strategies against the enemies and they were challenging. A lot of the late game enemies are just a chore though. No strategy really works, you just have to play the section ten times until you get lucky and kill them. And since the story is garbage there isn't really much reason to stick with it, it's just painful.It's extremely difficult, it will make you angry, it will make you cry, you will always die just before you reach the save point because you had to reload at an awkward time. Spare yourself some suffering, play Half Life or Halo 1 instead.

												I have great memories of playing the multiplayer on the original Xbox and Remade Xbox 360 version of this game so I bought this expecting a similar experience and oh my was I dissapointed. It is nothing like the console version and the multiplayer is boring and terrible. What made the multiplayer great on the consoles was the map editor which doesn't exist in this version nor do any custom maps appear online (which is dead, only 1-10 servers with only about 3 or 4 running with a maximum of 8 players if you're lucky) which is the only thing that really made Far Cry multiplayer worth playing.The campaign I didn't play much of, but it's really typical. I've been waiting for this game to hit 2.49 on sale for a while because a part of me KNEW I was going to be dissapointed and I wasn't wrong. I wouldn't recommend buying this even if it was 99 cents because it's honestly not worth the time in my opinion. The campaign is worth a playthrough I guess but you won't want to play it again.To get to the point, if you want it for the multiplayer, DO NOT BUY IT because it's basically non-existant. If you want it for the campaign then only buy it on sale because the experience isn't worth 10 dollars.

												Combines hitscan enemies with really long combat distances, quickly lost health that doesn't regenerate*, and AI that are cartoonishly acurate. Pass on this one.*Medkit-based FPS games only work if properly balanced. Doom, Quake, and F.E.A.R. are games that do it right. In the first two, it's because most enemy attacks can just be dodged. In F.E.A.R., it's because the game lets you a) slo-mo, b) permanently upgrade your health, and c) carry upto 10 medkits. Regenerating health suits games like Far Cry a lot better.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2014
												Far Cry 1 is a game that has aged surprisingly well. Especially from a graphics standpoint.It won't make Nvidia enthusiasts salivate. But it means that Crytek was able to churn out enough polygons and sfx to make it actually passable in the critical eyes of today's players.That is high praise, technically speaking, since 90s and early 2000s FPS usually look like something that came out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of Far Cry's Trigen Baboons. So maybe its historical legacy will be that - the first modern 3d game that has aged visually well.It's also very easy on modern gfx cards. It seems my GTX 460 breaks more sweat when rendering pixeled hipster games.So how is Far Cry in terms of play?It's really basic: A beautiful caribbean island, a shlocky story.You're shooting bad guys with guns, take their guns and run around, quite a lot actually. The most shocking features are a *omygawd* stamina bar, being able to *gasp* drop down and shoot from a prone position and *sweetjeezustheresmoar* shooting through many types of walls.This is all implemented solidly.More of FC's strengths: AI behaviour is great. Sound fx are fine.Some features were run-of-the-mill at the time, but may be received controversially today:No automatic bumwiping er... health regeneration I mean. Have fun backtracking!No excessive exposition. No military propaganda.And...caveat millenials ... NO QUICKSAVING. The game autosaves for you, rather fairly, I'd have to say. This might be a dealbreaker for many, but it actually works.If you're a fan of basic FPS, you can play Far Cry without blushing. It's alright. No shame in liking meat and potatoes, chart music or missionary, All others, pass. There's just too little substance.VERDICTDr. Krieger's ethics commision approves 2,5 out of 5 specimen.Decent, basic, passable - for FPS fans.

												I found it hard to see why people liked this game so much. I found it rather boring, frustrating and unstable. The gameplay is quite varied for an FPS but at no point did I find myself remotely caring what was going on. The AI of the enemy is rather good. They do things like try to out flank you and summon back up but this results in the difficulty of this game being ridiculous. Despite playing this on a high spec gaming PC built 5 years after the game came out I still had to knock the settings down to medium to even get the menu to load and it crashed frequently. This just added to the annoyance and the frustration.

content:
ry 12, 2015
												Probably the most overrated game I've ever played in my life.The GoodIt has good physics effects and animations considering the time it was made, that goes for the graphics as well which are quite beautiful and advanced also, it has decent AI, and Jack Carver is a relatively funny main character.The BadIt's a ridiculously unbalanced game in terms of difficulty, in the second easiest difficulty you'll find yourself doing several sections again and again and again and again and again (x10) for no other reason other than some enemies are more powerful than they should be, or simply because the game offers you no resources at all, you have your guns, you have your ammo, and you have your luck.It's also a terribly bland shooter, the only thing you'll be doing in this game is routing through the jungle trying to get the drop on mercenaries, or sometimes weird monsters, sometimes it won't be a jungle, it will be a generic concrete structure called "bunker" or "facility" without any real distinction or meaning.Finally, the story is almost nonexistant, it's only there to give sense to the gameplay, and whatever value it has, it only comes by the main character's ocasionally funny lines ... ocassionally.I bought the first three games, including the third one's expansion, for 10$.If the sequels are anything like the first one, then I might as well just have thrown those 10$ straight into a volcano.

number of helpful: 12 of 28 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												Undoubtedly a game that was impressive upon release, today, it finds itself done wrong by an overwhelmingly mediocre story, inconsistent difficulty, and general tedium, which leads me to not be able to recommend this game.Certainly, it wasn't immediately terrible, the early sections of the game, bar one helicopter sequence, have you traversing an island that would clearly have faint echoes in 2007's legendary Crysis, with impressive foilage and shooting action for 2004.  But as the game progresses, the enemies get dumber, the hallways get longer, and the game starts to wear on you.  The shooting never really evolves past hopping around the mutated enemies, or spraying hot lead in the general direction of humanoid ones.The story itself seems disinterested with you and your actions, with the closing third of the game feeling slightly tacked on just to pad length.  It's never really quite sure if it wants to be a parody of Rambo-style B movies from the 70s, or a completely serious and dull tale of the multitalented cardboard box that serves as the protagonists's personality.  Also in this final third, the difficulty reaches a cliff the likes of which had me reaching for Dwarf Fortress for relief.  The first of two final bosses proves to be a painful experience even on Normal difficulty, but far too easy on the easiest one.  There is a section nearly directly preceding it that has you running through the jungle from the mutants, where it's basically luck if you get hit or not by them, allowing you to progress.I may have gotten this game for very cheap, and even with no expectations, I came out feeling disappointed.

number of helpful: 9 of 22 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2014
												One of my least favorite games I've ever played. I played this game because I anticipate buying a new computer and getting the next-gen Far Cry games (3 and 4) so I decided to play the first and second games to see how they may compare. After playing this, I already know this is my least favorite out of the entire series.- Gunplay in this game is bland and repetitive. There's no variation in the combat whatsoever and after an hour or so it becomes the most boring thing ever. Plus it's very inconsistent, you can one-hit a guard with the suppressed MP5K then a minute later you can mow down the same type of guard with the M4 and kill him after half the mag is in his chest.- The NPCs are the worst. Seriously, being able to shoot through the walls at you in multiple situations after one of them has seen you is the worst. It makes so many parts of the game almost impossible. Their repetitive, bland voices make you want to cry. After about 30 minutes of hearing "I'm gonna shoot your face off!" and "I'm gonna lay down the smackdown!" I already wanted to gag myself with a spoon.- Speaking of voice acting, every person in this game with a speaking part makes me cringe. Especially the main character, his Nukem-esque voice and cliche one-liners become super annoying after the first moments of hearing him.- Some parts of this game are so hard they may even seem impossible (even on normal difficulty). The NPCs have some undying blood-lust rage even on the easiest setting. You should be able to have fun and rush whomever on the easiest difficulty but you can't do that and it's overkill in my opinion. Some parts like the mini-boss against Crowe on the sinking ship, where you have NO supplies around you and the game doesn't allow you to shoot while submirged in water so it's super difficult to get a shot off especially while Crowe is mowing you down with his LMG.- Some things, like the ability to look at a situation and decide where to go and what kind of way to take it (Like run-and-gun vs. a stealth approach.) made me happy early on, but later on it turned into "Okay, either turn right and get shot at or turn left and get shot at. Your choice bro.".- The story is strictly linear and boring. It's pretty predictable and the complete change in the enemies in the middle of the game was terrible. Especially since the "Trigens" are one-hit kill enemies (with no armour). It seems like a cool story at first and it looks like it'll end up being a pretty nice, open game but it's just so straight forward and linear. It's honestly super disapointing.Overall, I don't recommend this game. Maybe right now since it's just 6 bucks or in the bundle but only then. It's not worth the time you put into it.

content:
12, 2015
												So firstly i have never played any Far Cry game ever before playing this one in 2015.  This is because i like to play games in order of release and i recently bought a package in the Steam Winter sale 2014 which included Far Cry, Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon.  I cant remember how much the package was but it was super cheap.So this being my first ever Far Cry experience i went in knowing that this was released a long time ago and that it was an older game so didnt expect too much. I haven't really played any other games that i can compare this to within the same time period either so i don't really know what graphics/gameplay mechanics were like back then.So this game immediatly has terrible graphics in comparison to the film quality graphics of today but i assume they were probably pretty good for 2004 :P The game is basically mission based unlike Far Cry 4 (which i haven't played but believe is Open World??) so it does feel very linear, meaning you have to go down this set path to these set objectives even though there are occasionally multiple paths to the same place.The A.I is too sensitive or there is no option to sneak in this game since they appear to 'hear' you from what would seem well out of hearing range.  The A.I can 'hear' you through walls of buildings, they can see you and shoot you through buildings or tents. The health in this game is very very badly balanced with the enemies/difficulty too.  Since this game has no achievements i thought to myself 'i'll play on the easiest difficulty just so i can enjoy the game and walk through it no problem' LOL! Yeah so i somehow manage to take two bullets and my entire Armor and Health are basically depleted on the easiest difficulty. This just makes it too much of a pain to complete the missions for me and having put in what i believe to be a decent amount of effort and time trying to finish the game, i just can't bring myself to finish it because im dying too easily, the story isnt too interesting, the voice acting and all the cheesy lines are terrible and im just generally not enjoying playing it.So from me this game on its own i wouldn't reccomend but i will be playing Far Cry 2 next and so on, so maybe as a part of the Far Cry package it wouldn't be as bad.

content:
er 23, 2014
												Far Cry. Oh Far Cry.This game. This game is hard. And frustrating. Hell, it didn't even work properly on boot up. Nor did it work perfectly when it DID finally boot up. Had to turn down my settings to "High" and the shadows to "Medium" in order to get it working properly.But: First things first. You're a retired elite soldier, running some tourism boat tour company or some ♥♥♥♥. A young woman asks you to drive her all the way to a small collection of little islands because she wants to study ancient culture or whatever. A rocket strikes your boat on the way to the islands, you get stranded and then: The girl is from the CIA! Mercenaries want to kill you! Mutants! A nuclear bomb! More mutants! A volcano which is exruciatingly hard to get through! EVEN MORE MUTANTS! Oh and you have to stop the guy who created the mutants for humanity's sake, of course. And you get the girl. And everyone is happy in the end. Except for the tons of dead guys.That's pretty much the gist of it, really. Anyway, being top-notch at its time, Far Cry isn't all that bad. It's got decent game mechanics, outrageous physics and ok graphics. Well. It came out the same year as Half-Life². Go figure. What I dislike the most is that all the levels are split in, well, levels. No open world, just an arrangement of missions for you to fight your way through. And it's got bugs and glitches, making it possible to skip some sections entirely - or not being able to get through some sections at all. Also, it's hard to try and search for a different approach to any given mission, making it boring after one playthrough. No replayerability whatsoever. There's always an optimal way to get through this game and all the other ways are just painful.Speaking of painful: This game is hard. Even on medium difficulty you'll be running into enemies that do not hesitate to shoot a rocket straight in your face from 2 meters of distance, snipers that shoot with pinpoint accuracy from roughly 2 kilometers away so that you can't even SEE them because of the horrendous draw distance. Or just a big bunch of waaaay too strong mutants that come jumping at you and melee you to death in one or two hits.Also: The plot. It lacks any form of engagement. Halfway through I asked myself what my original objective was, why I'm on this island and why the hell I have to blow up three radio towers. I listened to the guy giving me the mission, I did. But it seemed just so irrelevant that I forgot five minutes after. And when I finally came to the last five levels I started asking myself "When does this end?". But I wanted to get through, just so that I beat this game.If you like AI behaviour that renders you defenseless on higher difficulties due to them shooting with pinpoint accuracy and onehitting you and if you like levels that only allow for one or two approaches at it and you don't care about any sort of plot, you might like Far Cry. Speaking for myself, I didn't like it too much and wouldn't recommend it. Unless you can get it quite cheap when Steam's got another deal. Then you can have a go at it. But otherwise... no. If you'd asked me 10 years earlier I would've said "WOW! This thing is AMAZING!". But today's standards do not allow this to happen.

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
28, 2015
												Having no nostalgia or rose tinted glasses for this game I can firmly say this game dousn't really stand well against the test of time. When it was new and innovative Im sure people looked at it like it was great. I can firmly say that this game isn't that great. Its definetly dated and in relative to game design of more recent its just inferior.Is it fun? Yeah, but more often than not I found I was having fun only to just die with no real idea who or what killed me or how. Then being forced to reload and play what might be a lengthy part of the game which ultimately undoes any fun it was the first time.  Also the fun is to few and far in between.Gameplay genereally revolves around getting from A to B and killing everyone who gets in the way in between. Sometimes B is an objective or a bomb you need to blow something up which means you need to go get the bomb then back track usually. Theres vehicles peppering the game that add some variety aswell as a myriad of weapons. Some of which are quite a bit more usefull than others. Theres a combination of both semi-open world maps and corridors though the game is best when outside in a semi-open world map where the AI is best to play againstThe AI has issues. They do that old thing games used to do (and bad games still do) where enemies will snap to you and shoot immediatly if you so much as poke your head out while they are alerted, while some other times they won't even be looking the right way or they will just stare at you. Or if your driving on a boat at full speed they will still be hitting you no matter how fast you are going. Its compounded by the fact tracers dont necesarrily follow where the bullets are traveling or hitting (which is especially common in older and cheaper games) so it can be hard knowing exactly if your hitting or what your getting hit by (next to no problem when your on foot shooting though when using mounted weapons it is). Another issue is that in close quarters the AI shoots so accurate and fast that with guns one guy can pretty much take most your armor and health away. Which while you did everything right, all it took was one rogue guy and a bad checkpoint and now your saved with less than 50% hp and no armor.  Luckily theres usually not much terraferma between health and armor, though sometimes it can be quite a drag to get to them. Ironically regenerating HP would actually make this game more enjoyable especially with how difficult it is and how little damage you can take anyway. An issue I have found is that RPG guys are way to often. RPG wielding enemies will shoot from ridiculous ranges at you, fortunately RPGS travel pretty slow but its still annoying especially with the blast radius. Another point about explosions, they are very inconsistant. If you shoot a rocket anywhere near a vehicle (such as using the jeep mounted RPG to blow guys out of cover) and even relatively far away you will 1 shot kill yourself. I think I played this on challenging, so I advise playing it on normal or easy, unfortuantely on easy and normal the AI are pretty stupid and can just barely hit you with my testing. Yep, its one of those games where instead of making the AI linearly more challenging its basically a cliff of difficulty.The mutants are an interesting addition but have so little variety that theres only like 3 or 4 diffrent ones and compared to the humans they arn't fun to fight due to little or no tactics but they can kill you with incredible ease in some cases. But by the end of the game theres a over reliance on mutants with rocket launchers to make it difficult and it really stops being interesting by then. They soak up so much damage that its easier in most cases to just go past or around them and since you move so slow it can be hard to dodge away from them and their spalsh damage which again is the reason I prefer not to fight them.It gets worse when your going up against armored guys who will soak up anything short of a headshot (So thats where Far Cry 2 got that design idea from...) And the inconsistant nature of the AI just gets worse. Some bushes that should conceal you the AI might see right through and get alerted and shoot you, while the opposite also happens. Sometimes AI decides they want to dump a magazine and hit you with a good number of rounds while at medium distance. Though for all its bad, the AI does try basic tactics such as sneaking and they do exhibit independant like thinking capabilities. Instead of the game saying you are here (which does happen) the AI will exhibit cases where NPCs will search for you and while one may find you the others wont be informed of your location in the world until they learn of it. Or atleast thats what it seems like, its not as good as Far Cry 2 and both pale in comparison to Arma and mil sim games. The mutants don't seem to do much in terms of tactics though.Saving is not very good. Unlike past games like Doom or HL1 saves are check point based and not very good. Sometimes they are to far between and with no capability to save yourself you are at the will of the save system. So a shoot out your having trouble getting past means you have to reload and get back to the fight just to try to get past it.  These days check points and auto saving is much better than this but this is far from that and really needed a manual save.Vehicles pepper the world and levels and offer variance to the gameplay which is especially nice with the boat levels as they are some of the largest levels and offer the most tactical choices aswell as looking the best. I really like the reflection in water when used in games. Unfortunately land mass dousn't usually get reflected due to a glitch in the steam version regarding modern OS compatability if I remember.Compatability wise, the game is just barely there. Im honestly surprised the game actually works and dousn't crash or have many issues. Its advisable to download a fan made updated (1.41) or some other mods that make it so enemies dont see through buildings (primarily tents and shacks how the f*ck did that get through QA?) aswell as some address other glitches or add stuff to the game. If you can help it, don't buy the Steam version but instead buy the GOG version.  Sometimes when I try to close the game the game will give a black screen and keep running. As I said it just barely works.The story is a throw away. Its like the John Carmack quote. The story here is just ultimately to give you a reason to go kill and shoot people and its pretty stupid and goofy but not entertaining on its own or anything worth mention.The GOG version costs the same and is more open aswell comes from a truly free (freedom wise) service in terms of DRM.I wouldn't recommend this game unless you are heavy into classic FPS games or unless your looking for a decent but hard FPS game. If you just want a good or great game this just isn't it, Far Cry 2 is better in some aspects especially gameplay though so I would recomend that one more so. If you really care about the Far Cry series your not missing much if anything at all. If you do want to play it don't put it above normal and maybe even easy and it might even be worth it to stop playing the game before you get to the latter levels as story wise and mechanics wise your missing nothing. Best parts are when your in an open area and fighting humans anyway. Also the final fight is intensly difficult for what feels like all the wrong reasons. Its all the worst parts of the game put together to just make it hard. So theres nothing your going to miss if you stop playing before the final mission or around the time the game turns more into a corridor shootery type game.

content:
y 27, 2015
												-Updated 1/28/15-How to begin this review? Firstly, thank you to Rinon for buying me this game. Now with the pleasantries over with I can go into the meat of the review. Yes, this is an eleven year old game, but even on my rather decent gaming rig I was getting graphical artifacts, crashes and not even being able to play the game for what little I played. I purchased this game retail when it came out in '04, and my memories were true. Crytek make pretty engines, but horrible games. With enemies that can instakill you on moderate difficulty before you are within visual range of them, enemies that have models that pop in out of nowhere, and constant, frustrating artifacts the game was unplayable for me on each and every setting. Audio was a joke, as my headphones could just barely pick up voices and/or sounds even when at the maximum volume. Normally my OCD requires me to play each and every game in a series, but for now - I am skipping over to Far Cry 2. Your results with this game might vary, but in my opinion - do not get your hopes up.-Update 1/28/15-Another three hours of wrangling with the game and all I ended up with was a pair of BSODs, an overheated GPU, and a full on crash that forced me into safe mode. I hate to do this but I am going to have to urge others not to purchase this game, it could damage modern hardware if my results are any proof.

												The enemy AI is SO broken. At first the combat is fun and the game seems solid, but then you learn that enemies can see you through walls and that, while the game instructs you to move stealthily through areas to avoid fighting, you cannot sneak past enemies. content:
ber 8, 2014
												3/10An utterly frustrating, disappointing and enraging game.Worthless minimap, no world map at all, no manageable inventory, no character progression, 7 weapons in all of the game (including a useless machete, a pistol only the weakest NPC's use and a rocket launcher you will never need).Also just one piece of repeatable armor and only one occasional way of healing which you can't even carry around.The story must have taken them like 1 hour to write, seeing that you are just thrown intothe thick of it and later on (unlike later far cry 3) you aren't told the story either.Insane damage from even the most simple of enemies even in medium difficulty that I played, regardless of their positioning (hit you through cover and with their sight obscured by objects), INSANE sight range for some enemies (last case of that I encountered was getting shot at ACCURATELY by RPG's from a distance so big that I couldnt even spot the enemy with my binoculars). No valuable long term stealthy gameplay either, due to the aforementioned factors, as well as the enemy being able to hear your movement on a certain radius (this is waht makes the machete totally worthless, seeing that the hearing radius is grater than your mellee range) and no silenced weapons being available (not even the sniper rifle, which will triger NPC alertness no matter out of what range you are shooting. You as a player are OFC unable to hear the enemy snipers shots).No replay value what so ever seeing that there is no RPG immersion, no decisions to make, no nothing. The same story over and over again.This game is a bit like COD, only that you have insane NPC's instead of noob kids ruining the game. Hell, some NPC's are even campers!On the other hand to get through some places you will have to start thinking, meaning that the progression isn't obvious or given to you by the game, even the descriptionless objectives and close to useless minimap add to this.Finally, to be fair, I have to admit that I didn't try multiplayer, which, if good, could at some points to the game (in case you still find anyone playing vanilla Far Cry, that is).

content:
er 7, 2014
												This game started out fun and interesting but has quickly turned into a game that I very sincerely regret buying. It was a complete waste of money, and I rarely say that about any game. The only reason I am still playing it at this point is because I have a thing about finishing all of my games. It looks good enough for a 2004 title, the voice acting is bad but forgiveable (nothing can be worse than Resident Evil), and the maps are large and sem-open, but that's where it ends. The stairs and ladders are bugged, the AI Balance function isn't actually a functional function, the enemies are OP and can one-shot you from clear across the map, the stealth mechanics don't work, you can't exit the game without it crashing on you, and probably the worst thing: there is NO manual save. Well, there is, but it's way too much of a pain in the ♥♥♥ to do. It involves altering some game files in developer mode. So yeah. The game auto-saves at the worst possible locations, so I found myself having to cover the same expanses of map and doing the same things over and over and over and over again until I got lucky enough to make it to the next checkpoint. Like I said, if it weren't for this thing I have about finishing my games, I'd give up on this piece of junk.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
10, 2016
												There's this strange belief that's been circulating since 2004 that Far Cry is somehow a good game, I know, I know, it's too ludicrous to be true.But it is, and it's still here, that strange, unfathomable belief is still here.And as I play it, I wonder to myself, why? Why after having climbed a ladder to engage in the game's first "boss" fight am I immediately assaulted by a helicopter, six goons, and a microsecond to react, rendering me robbed of almost all my health and at the mercy of maybe one or two more hitscan shots before I am murdered in an abysmal display of horrendous level design?Why do I continue to meander around in floaty vehicles with terrible physics as annoying goons fling rockets at me from the ocean in an extravagant play of profoundly dull encounter design?As I marvel at how intensely dull and uninteresting the weapons are, I become overwhelmed by a miasma of ennui, I slowly realize nothing about this game was designed for my enjoyment, instead it was created by some hellish idiot who thinks that suffering is synonymous with "challenge."Garbage boring mutants will leap at you in a room discharging rockets in every direction, and as you try to manuever your way through the 4x4 space, you will scream in futility as you pound bullet after bullet into succesful headshot, only to fell the garbage boring mutants after your 16th round. Insane men screaming at you to "bite my ♥♥♥" will do about-faces and physically combine into a super hivemind that will immediately know if the single man you murdered 50 miles away died by your hand after you tactically distracted him with the infinite supply of rocks your character materializes out of a pocket dimension he carries in his massive ♥♥♥♥♥♥, they will then proceed to ventilate you with hyper-accuracy, utilizing horrifying magicks to warp physics and have their low caliber weaponry forcefully pound tiny bullets into your small-minded, idiot brained character's puny skull from continents away and promptly kill you very fast.People on the forums will then tell you to be stealthy, as the mercenaries within the game prove that they are masters of evil wizardry, and will reach out of the game into our reality to cast confusion spells upon the residents of the Steam forums and turn them into drooling nincompoops who refuse to accept the truth that is around them, that Far Cry was deisgned by a coven of extremely hateful and ugly witches who want nothing more than to subject humanity to pure pain and agony.It's really quite ridiculous, and almost every part of this game just suffuses with loathing for the player, the omniscient enemies that will lazer you through bushes, the impotent level design that seems to think long corridors with little deviation is interesting "open" level design, the obnoxious, confoundingly idiotic story and brutally ♥♥♥♥-poor voice over.You'll even start to notice how crap the visual feedback is, how stunningly unsatisfying it feels when you finally DO down the bulletsponge enemies, how every weapon feels weak and clunky, how generally unsatisfying and lame every aspect of the engine is that isn't about the graphics.This game gives me a huge headache, this game fills you with that really lame sense of frustration after every quickload where you feel compelled to finish the game, like an obligation, but unlike real world obligations, the only thing you get out of this one is the game putting its donger in your mouth.Speaking of quickloads, there is no manual saves or quicksaves, you have to use a cheat code to save yourself, in this hellish nightmare of a game, they don't even give you this one simple mercy. Out there, the designers of Far Cry are assuming their true shapes, massive brain eating slugs that have been gestating in the liquid magma core of the earth, rising up to pee all over your face invisibly with invisible pee as you play this game.Juicy 2004 graphics though.That's literally the one thing that's good about Far Cry, the graphics, the graphics were great, absolutely great for 2004.Now it's 2016, and the game looks like dated feces.And now it only sucks, it doesn't even look pretty while it sucks, and it doesn't even provide you with the courtesy of a real life donger for your mouth.I hate this game.

content:
31, 2014
												The short version: bland selection of weapons, laughable stealth mechanics, and inflated, artless difficulty in a pathetic bid for cred as a tactical shooter. A worthless non-plot even by video game standards, to the point where the usual juvenile BS barely even registers as campy or offensive. No, Steam, I don't recommend this game.The long version:The weapons are boring. You have your choice of (thus far at least, I'm not finishing this thing): assault rifle, two SMGs (one useless), rocket launcher, sniper rifle (rare), shotgun, pistol (useless), and machete (useless). Obviously not every game needs a sweeping array of whimsical fantasy weaponry, but a big part of shooters for me is bonding with my favorite guns and none of these dull gray slabs cut it.The story is not worth a turd. The player character has bad cringey voice acting, no real qualities but a sort of flat, lazy sarcasm, and no will of his own, only taking orders from a voice on his phone. A female partner is teased early on but shows up in a cutscene tackily emulating Ursula Andress in Dr. No only to disappear again for hours.The graphics are nice for their time. Vegetation--bushes, grass, vines, leaves--was (and often still is) one of polygonal graphics' big weaknesses; setting a shooter on a tropical island must have seemed like an impossible dream to many. And yet the jungle gets monotonous fast. You can (literally) go off the beaten path and explore around and sometimes find alternate paths through a level, but doing so never feels worth it because you can't actually sneak past enemies (more about that later). Indoor levels don't even have graphics or exploration going for them. Cement fortresses filled with catwalks and computer equipment. Sewers and tunnels with no sign of vermin and that don't seem particularly dirty or smelly. Blah.Movement is awkward. You can't go very fast, even when sprinting, which depletes a stamina bar and broadcasts your location to every enemy within a city-block radius. You'll be spending most of the game semi-stealthed in a crouch position by holding CTRL but even then enemies can easily spot you. Interacting with the environment sucks too, you have to be flat up against and aiming perpendicular to and directly at whatever it is you want to pick up or use. So doing anything actually badass, like using a keycard to jump through a door in the middle of a firefight, or killing a dude, grabbing his gun, and killing the next dude with it, is next to impossible. Oh, and the ladders! I forgot about the ladders. The suckitude of ladders in this game doesn't even deserve explanation. ♥♥♥♥ you, ladders! Far Cry is also, as others have noted, too goddam hard. Enemies a mile away can detect you and kill you to death in under a second. There's also godawful pop-in that prevents you from seeing distant enemies. Frequently you'll die suddenly from someone you can't even see or hear. Once, I discovered this was because the enemy was headshotting me FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF AN OPAQUE TENT. The stealth mechanics, with the exception of the night vision, are next to useless, and it even features that ultimate early-2000s PC FPS frivolity, the "lean" movement bound to Q and E. The best you can hope for with stealth is to position yourself for a firefight and maybe take out the first one or two guys (often of ten or more, mind you) in an area. You have radar and can use the binoculars to mark enemies on it, but doing so is a false sense of security because it usually won't see everyone, and those one or two guys it didn't catch will get the drop on you. And even successfully being stealthy isn't the best choice, because guys you sneak past will come running to find you next time they hear gunshots. You can't hear enemies coming because they make no footstep noises; if you're lucky you'll hear some stupid taunt like "I'm-a gonna gun yer face to helllllll!" or whatever but those voice clips always sound closer than they really are. This is all on the default "Medium" difficulty, by the way.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2014
												Story:Ehhhhhh...ewwww.....really Ubisoft? Another mad scientist with his attempt at making super humans, but it goes wrong and then they go rogue. Great...I really need another game where this happens. OH I'm trying to escape the island!?! Why don't I just use one of the last 17 boats I got into to escape?!? NO I have to use them to go from small island to other small island. NEVER back to the mainland. I mean I got here on a sailboat I think  could make it back with a tank of gas so don't give me that excuse. And then there is Valarie...screw Valarie. I don't care! I have no idea who she is! There was no character development. I mean I love a game where you get chucked into it and you have to figure everything out, but when I'm told to go save someone whom I have no relation to? That's just bad design. It ceases to become a game and it becomes work. Maybe they should give me an incentive to go after her? Make me want to save her not just tell me to in order to justify their game and provide an excuse for, frankly, sub-par level design.Playability:This is where the game took a turn for the worse, I mean really worse. The AI was one of the most disgusting things in the world. Think Sonic '06 level of broken. I mean almost completely broken. The so called “stealth” would never work. You could be 100 yards away, prone in a bush, and you would hear “There he is!” and start getting shot at. They constantly “see” you before you even enter the room, and once I was spotted while prone INSIDE A VENTALATION SHAFT! All this combined with constantly being shot through walls or the guy INSIDE the garage but lit you up from a car's turret regardless makes the game most aggravating. Another moment was when you were told that the entrance to the boat was a hole in the side. Well guess what? They didn't mean the big obvious hole in the side. It was a small entrance near the bow of the ship. It took me about 10 minutes of jumping against a wall before I thought “Maybe the hole isn't this hole? Maybe there is another? Maybe Ubisoft pulled a fast one on me?” Even with all of these pitfalls, by no means is it a difficult game. Just repetitive and annoying. So many things were included in the game to make it longer. It felt like an ordeal, so when you beat it you wouldn't want to have to go through it again providing the illusion of difficulty. They used level design to act as a difficulty supplement, not make it actually hard. Honestly, when I see a game company do this they lose a lot of respect. Level Design:“Open world” another great joke from Ubisoft. They obviously think open-world means “go here, then here, then here, then big battle, then go here.” They were extremely linear and after awhile just left a weird taste in you mouth like you get after drinking milk and then not drinking anything else for an hour. It became “Great...another building” and there was a lot of “Here I am shooting a near-identical person in a near-identical situation as the last few hundred.” It just wears you out. The addition of checkpoints just proves my point. You cant have checkpoints in a non-linear game. They just made the game even more linear. The only way you can save is if you go along the per-defined path layed out for you. Additionally, there are no side quests. I'm not saying that side quests are a mandatory feature of every game, but in an open world game, they certainly are.Graphics:Rather good, but honestly Counter-strike source and Metal Gear Solid 3 had better graphics and they were released in the same year. One redeeming feature was the draw distance in Cry-engine is vast which required little loading time.Overall:“A glorified tech demo, don't bother unless you're curious about how advanced graphics could get back in 2004.” -Crisis from SteamIt made me laugh, and I agreed so I figured I'd re-post it.

number of helpful: 11 of 29 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 14, 2014
												There are two types of challenging games. The first type is the one where you get killed a lot because you ♥♥♥♥ed up, and you know you ♥♥♥♥ed up. Super Meat Boy. Dark Souls. Then there's the type of game where you get killed a lot because the design is cheap and unfair. That's Far Cry.Far Cry is an absolute chore to play through. You will need to persist through piles of inexplicably bad design and an ungodly amount of unfair deaths to trial-and-error your way to the best tactic. Get Lucky or Die Quickly. It's finishable, but why would you want to? It's just not fun.SO HERE'S HOW IT WORKS.The game uses a checkpoint system, so quicksaving through a map when things are going well is not an option. You usually have the choice of fighting or using stealth. If you use stealth, be prepared to move VERY SLOWLY while crouched or prone, which saps the joy out of staying hidden. It can take a long time to traverse the map like this, and since enemies have such keen perception, you'll probably get spotted most times anyway. Not keen in the fair sense though. Keen because they can hear your footsteps from hundreds of feet away behind a building, or one of them can see you through the dense foliage you're hiding in because your shirt is so ♥♥♥♥ING RED, and they can all shoot through solid objects with unerring accuracy because they all have x-ray vision. Getting spotted after a 5-10 minute stealth creep and reloading a checkpoint isn't fun.So the alternative? Run and gun. This is a mixed proposition. It can feel good when it works, and the combat is nice and responsive, but you will get flanked and taken down constantly. Far Cry employs a health pack system with very few health packs, so again, 10-minute checkpoints need to be played over and over again because it just takes that one ♥♥♥♥ing guy out of the 25 you fought to get around your flank and it's die, redo. It reminded me a lot of Call of Duty 2 on Veteran mode (anybody?), but I was playing on normal.Here's how the ROCKET LAUNCHERS work. Mercs and mutants with rocket launchers fire them in such quick succession that if any one of them gets the bead on you, you are literally too slow to outrun them. If you DO stay ahead of the rocket stream, the smoke keeps you perpetually blind while the screen shakes, thus making it IMPOSSIBLE for you to fight back. Rocket launcher guys are usually a half-mile away as well, so die, reload. It's like playing Doom 2, except that you can only take one hit before death and the bad guys can shoot through walls and also, you have crazy glue on the bottom of your shoes. Not fun!Die, reload. You will die a lot. Maybe you'll get a checkpoint, but it will be in the middle of combat. Remember that rocket stream I just told you about? I got a checkpoint once while there were two rockets in the air sailing towards me. Die, reload, die, reload, die, reload, can't escape, restart entire mission. Thanks Far Cry!The combat is functional in the corridor sections, but in wide-open spaces, it's just a matter of exploiting the AI in cheap ways and engaging from long distances to avoid any real conflict. The best strategy: go for headshots while the AI is non-reactive to your presence and they're just standing there like target dummies. Or wait for them to get caught in a ridiculous movement loop and time your shot. Not fun!Your health, even on easy mode, is laughably minimal, and the hardcore difficulty of the game is mostly caused by the AI's impossibly keen sense, unerring accuracy, and your ability to absorb about 2 1/2 bullets before dying. Not fun!I got halfway through the game and realized I had no idea what was going on or why this dude was on this island or why the voice actors talk like they're not taking their jobs or this game seriously at all.I wouldn't either, the script and story are a pile of feces.At one point a mercenary shouts, "YOU'RE GONNA WISH YOU WERE DEAD!" -- while he's unloading his machine gun at me. Try to make sense of that.Spoiler alert: there are mutants, and they look like rejected Quake 2 designs.This entire game has no idea what its identity or focus is.You can't even blame 2004 for this. Half-Life 2 came out a few months later and was perfect in every way, while Doom 3 even succeeds in topping this game with its focused combat and sharp atmosphere. And Doom 3 sucked.I would rather contract malaria than play this game again. I guess I'll play the sequel.3.5/10

												This would of been a great game to get in 2004, but now ten years later; this game is boring, has seemingly repetitive gameplay with small tweaks in the objectives you are doing, terrible voice acting but suprisingly good audio quality, and obviously this game has the graphics of a game from 2004, like it should. The only reason that I own this game is because of the Steam Summer Sale of 2014 and I bought the Far Cry Franchise Pack, which including; this game, Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3, and Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon.The only reason I would suggest getting this game is in the Far Cry Franchise Pack, but if you already have the other Far Cry games, don't bother buying this title.

content:
er 28, 2013
												I never thought I would play a game where the console version is infinitely better than the PC version, but if ever there were such a thing, this is perhaps the most extreme case.  This might be the worst game I have ever played.  The graphics and draw distance are nice considering the times (tho I found the texture pop-up annoying), the gunplay is acceptable, but these were clearly the only things that any thought was put into; the obnoxious, flaky AI consists mostly of wall-hacking aimbots (in fact, a user had to create an unofficial patch to fix bots being able to see and shoot through certain surfaces, which made the game unplayable for me.  To be clear, that's a USER doing the DEVELOPER's job for FREE), and combined with an archaic checkpoint system with no manual or quick-save, you can anticipate spending hours of your life replaying the same 10mins between checkpoints overandoverandoverandover sluggishly advancing through the occasionally engaging maps.  The game seems to encourage or give the option of stealth at times, but with AI like this, I gave that up by the third level.  Some games are frusturating but highly rewarding, but I never even felt any sense of reward overcoming each obnoxious "challenge", only dreading the fact the game wasn't over yet and there was still plenty of hell ahead.  I wasn't even a little pleased until it was over, but not at all pleased with all that wasted time I will never get back.  If you're going to make a game this bad, at least have generous save systems so we don't have to put up with it for so long.  I can't think of anything with worse voicovers and dialouge that takes itself seriously (one character was clearly voiced by a close relative of Microsoft Sam).  If this is good writing, than Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone and The Rock more than deserve Oscars for their latest masterpieces.  There is absolutely no charm, not even in the context of the B-movie sense, which I can appreciate.  Even the soundtrack is awful and uninspired.  This comes off to me as one of these elitist "tech demo" (if I may quote the great Steamcast host spitfire ♥) games that exist soley for people to invest lots of money into their computer so they can gawk at the graphics and brag about how they can afford the hardware to run it at highest video settings.  The PC library wouldn't be complete without them; there's at least one or two every year, and each one pushes back mainstream acceptance of PC gamers a little further.  But it's almost 2014.  Graphics have moved forward from where they were a decade ago.  So the only reason this was worth playing to begin with is beyond obsolete.  All this is not to suggest good graphics are ALWAYS a bad thing, but they must supplement the experience, not BE the experience.  I was appalled at the few threads I came accross debating whether this or Half-Life 2 is better.  If you are interested in this game or even if you've already played it and like it, I can't recommend enough playing Far Cry: Instincts (unfortunately only on Xbox and Xbox 360) instead.  Despite essentially being a corridor shooter, it almost mirrors the PC version; the voice-overs - featuring Stephen Dorff as a Jack Carver that actually resembles a human - are stellar, the dialouge and story are at the very least decent if not good, the maps are much more atmospheric and in the case of the sequel Far Cry: Instincts - Evolution, I would say absolutely breathtaking at times, Paul Haslinger's soundtrack is some of the best I've ever heard, and the execution overall is much better.  So play that, and not this; this will drain many hours from your life and offer nothing interesting in return.P.S. Thankyou Valve for allowing us to not recommend games.  Long overdue.

content:
ry 28, 2014
												TL;DR version: Dying everywhere in 1 hit, on easy difficultyA decent shooter. It has good graphics for a game made in 2004, interesting combat mechanics and vehicles. It runs well on my machine too without any lag, even at 1600x900 resolution which usually lags for most games.However, the difficulty is insanely ridiculous, even though I am playing it at Easy difficulty after reading how people say how difficult the game is, and they aren't wrong. Enemies deal a megaton of damage, and I often have to retry the same portion more than 20 times, which is absolutely frustrating. Many reasons for this is getting surrounded by far too many enemies, getting one-shotted by rockets, or getting killed almost instantly by a machine gun once I pop my head out. The shotgun is useless junk, because it is a close-range weapon which cannot 1-shot the mutants at medium range, and I can't get to close range because they deal massive damage if I do (about 50% of my HP in one hit). The person talking to the protagonist is also speaking too softly, and a lack of subtitles doesn't help. The game is also buggy. I keep getting shot through the walls, and getting hit by rockets when I see absolutely no enemies around me. The "stealth" part of the game is to hide in tall grasses and bushes, but it is absolutely inconsistent. Sometimes even though I am hiding in them, I get spotted immediately. I also cannot fire an RPG onto a helicopter above me because the AOE is way too huge, and somehow it sends me flying 20 metres into the air upwards and fall down to death.I do agree that this is a decent game but if a game frustrates me most of the time, then it is not fun, and I cannot recommend it. I have played games like Batman: Arkham City and Arkham Origins, where sometimes I have to try 20 times or more to get it right too, but at least I knew what I was doing wrong and I had a chance. In Far Cry, as I stated earlier, I get one-shotted mostly, and getting one-shotted is stupid. Not to mention the tons of bugs.Rating: 4/10

												I'm a middle-aged gamer.  Been gaming since the Commodore 64.  I just picked this up in the Far Cry pack.  Having never played these games before just now, I feel my impression of the game is not clouded by nostalgia.  I'm unimpressed.  The opening cinematic tries to be epic and action-packed but ends up making no sense at all.  I gather some chick blew up my boat, I fell into the water - into a volcano, but not...then I get to land but there are monsters?  Then there are guys shooting at me for no reason and I end up back in the water?  I'm completely confused as to what the premise of this game is.Gameplay - Yes the graphics are a little dated but that doesn't bother me.  The problem I have is the gameplay.  The dude swims like he has a blood alcohol content of .99.  I get it, it's water.  But I shouldn't go from pointing straight ahead to looking straight down/up.  The other beef I have is with the pistol.  I get that it's supposed to be relatively innaccurate.  But if I'm 5 feet away from some guy, I point at his head, fire, see the bullet trail go towards his head, yet I completely miss, that's a problem.Luckily I have some other games in the franchise to try out.  If I had purchased this on its own I'd be very disappointed.

content:
ry 8
												Wow, now Far Cry is a perfect example how nostalgia and hype by its time can make a game better than it actually is.I remember the media and gaming community back then in 2004 going absolutely nuts about this game, declaring it as one of the best first person shooter experiences to ever have seen the light of the world. Especially in German-speaking countries the fan circlejerk was out of this world, since Crytek, back then still a small German developer team, was now seen as the new Valve or iD.But playing this over ten years later AT MOST charms a worn-out smile from me.Yes, the outdoor firefights against mercernaries are pretty good at first. Driving around in patrol boats or buggys is fun too. The island surroundings are still nice to look at, even nowadays. These parts hold up about 6 hours into the game.But as soon as the story introduces the mutants, everything goes down the drain. Some parts are sloppily designed, the gameplay gets significantly worse. Characters, story and voice acting are garbage. The final battle and the ending are miserable.After 12 hours you're happy to finally see ending, but disappointed why the rest of the game couldn't be like the first half. Meh.

content:
7, 2016
												This game was really a big let down for me. Back in the day in school I've heard of the great new shooter Far Cry. Everybody was so hyped about this.I finally played it since I got it in a game collection. I immediately noticed some things that really bugged me. But the real bad things came later throughout the game.First of all this game clearly sets the difficulty level high. So even on Normal difficulty I experienced quite skilled enemies with XRay vision and a not really clear priority list. You got to parties fighting each other and you, the Tridgen and the Mercenaries. They are in an all out war together, but once you just peek around the corner everything doesn't matter until you are dead, the teamed up on me every time, which made it really really hard to get past some choke points.The next thing is the far sight, which was highly praised by the developers, seemed to be only for the landscape (which really is beatiful, good job there). The enemies were faded out over long distances, which didn't seem to bother them at all to snipe me down with an M4, while I HAD to zoom in with the sniper to just be able to see them. This thing alone cost me about 2 hours in whole.Then came the glitches. Having two armies standing in a room, fighting each other, while staying back in order to thin them out worked like a charm. But once I entered some specific rooms the dead where still standing making it almost impossible to figure out the real survivors before getting shot. But this just adds to all the other things I encountered, like, invincible enemies to a certain trigger, recurring sounds once you step over the tirgger again, stuck sounds which sounds like someone just keeps shooting even so you got him already, strange rackdoll effects which block you view etc etc. the list goes on and on.That wouldn't be much of a problem, since many game encounter those bugs, even so not many have almost all of them , but once you are dead you have to start from the last autosave which can be about 30 minutes in the past. I had to play for 2 hours to get past a certain point in the river chapter, since you have to take out about 40 guys with choppers, patrol boats and rocket launcher, without having the game savin even once.The story itself is quite what you expect from a shooter this scale, but the cutscenes always cut out a second to early so you sometimes miss the last word.Well after all this game is quite old, so maybe I judge to hard, but I definetily can not recommend this game to anyone who is no masochist.Finished in 11 hours on normal, which could have been done in about 6 hours without the problems above...

content:
er 14, 2014
												I lost interest in the game around the 4th or 5th level. It's not that it is bad, but it's outdated for my tastes, especially after having played Far Cry 3. If you're playing for the story, don't. The protagonist's voice acting and lines are meant to be cliche and "funny," but they aren't - they come off as bad jokes. The story is poor and the cutscenes are laughable; I'm serious, just watch one and you will see what I mean. In terms of gameplay, it's alright. I don't understand why some people claim the A.I is "intelligent." I played on Hard and all I had to do was wait for them to pop out the corner and shoot them, or stay constantly alert at all times to watch out for those who stupidly stay in the same spot the entire time to insta-kill you. There is no aiming down the sights - if that's a "thing" that you need to get immersed, don't expect it. Other than that, it's an okay game. I wouldn't recommend playing it unless you seriously have to.

er 2, 2014
												When Far Cry asks players to duke it out with an army of gun-toting mercenaries in the middle of a jungle, it’s just about the perfect FPS.  Thinking tactically is the name of the game when sight lines, cover, and topography must be taken into account to have any chance at success.  So what’s the problem?  It’s that this is just a fraction of the experience, and the endless string of monsters in the middle of the campaign is neither challenging to fight, nor terrifying to behold.  Combine this with characters that nobody cares about, and a shallow story that had the potential to rival BioShock's if it had been done correctly, and you wind up with a product that cannot compare to more recent shooters.For a full review, check out:http://amanandhismouse.com/far-cry.html

content:
r 13, 2014
												Because I didn't play FC as a child and thus am not wearing rose-colored glasses, i can say that Far Cry has not aged well. Normally, I'd forgive an older game of a few bad bits, but this one in particular committed one of the greatest sins in the entertainmet industry: it put me off the rest of the series.I got this game as a 2-pack with FC2, and after 2 hours, I couldn't take the poor gameplay, nonexistent story, and inconsistent AI any longer. I put it down and never looked back. Well, I did try again a year later on an easier difficulty, and with cheat codes, but Far Cry fails to entertain. It tries to pawn off some stealth mechanics, but the AI across the whole map instantly knows exactly where you are if you so much as throw a distraction rock. This forces you to engage in combat, but far cry's gunplay is terrible and unstisfying, plagued with weapons that can't be aimed (yay random chance deciding if you can hit anyone!) and fire frozen peas intead of bullets. This left FC2 just sitting in my library, gathering dust. I wanted nothing to do with a sequel to the awful mess that is Far Cry. Eventually, I launched FC2 out of boredom, and was floored. Far Cry 2 is one of the best FPS adventures I have ever played. The fact that the same people made both games boggles my mind.

content:
8
												As a warning to fans of the more recent Far Cry games, I'll start off by saying that this is NOT an open-world game,l. It's a linear game that has much larger maps than most FPS games and allows you to approach your objective in a variety of different ways. The plot is simple, but no one plays Far Cry games for their plots; you assume the role of Jack Carved, an ex Special Ops operative with a terrible sense of fashion who becomes stranded on an island while transporting a reporter named Valerie there. You eventually discover that a mad scientist named Krieger is experimenting on primates and turning them into some of the most annoying enemies you'll ever face in a After playing for awhile, you may notice that this game had a heavy influence on Crysis, and they share many similarities. Both games: Are developed by Crytek using the Cryengine Are set on a tropical island Are linear but give you freedom in how you approach your objective Blinded critics to gameplay flaws by looking amazing at the time of their releases Introduce enemies that are a pain to fight partway through Have multiplayer modes that are now unplayable without modsAs I mentioned before, there's many ways to approach each objective and battle despite the game's linearity. This is helped by the wide variety of weapons you can use. You can kill foes from medium range with assault rifles, eliminate them from afar with the sniper rifle, let the enemies come to you and peak from behind cover to get quick kills with the automatic shotgun, and more. The only strategy that doesn't work is going in guns blazing, as you can buy killed in seconds on even Normal difficulty if you're not careful. Even if you're an FPS veteran who thinks that anything less than the highest difficulty in a game is child's play, I'd strongly recommend playing on High difficulty or lower, and I can explain why in one word: Trigens.Trigens are the aforementioned mutated primates, and they are a the game's weakest aspect. On Normal difficulty, the unarmed Trigens can kill you in just a few hits when you have full armor and health, and half the time they may not appear to even hit you when you take damage from them. Things only get worse later in the game when you must face humans that have become mutated and are capable of wielding guns. Some of them are simply tankier soldiers, but you sometimes massive brutes with rocket launcher arms that can withstand multiple grenades or several shotgun blasts to the face at point blank as well as invisible Trigens. Making this even worse is the fact that this game uses a checkpoint system. This game will be much more enjoyable if you take advantage of the console command "\save_game". It essentially allows you to quicksave, and will saves you loads of trial and error.While the Trigens are certainly more annoying than the human mercenaries, they can be pretty irritating as well due to their impossibly good vision which NPCs in the other game in the series thankfully don't have. Even in this dead of the night, enemies will be able to instantly spot you from several hundred meters away if they face your direction. This isn't a problem for the most since their chances of hitting you with bullets are pretty much zero, but be prepared to die A LOT of they have rocket launchers.It's worth noting that for its time, Far Cry looked fantastic. Even to this day, the models and water look fairly decent in my opinion, and I was especially impressed by the dynamic shadows that are cast on your weapon by foliage. I have no clue how well optimized the game is or if it runs well on the recommended hardware, as I have a GTX 1070 GPU which was unsurprisingly able to run the with settings turned up beyond their in-game menu limits at 1080p 60 FPS without any issues aside from the game sometimes freezing for a second or so when I threw a smoke grenade.Despite my frustrations with the Trigens and the weak plot, I'd still recommend Far Cry. When there's no mutants involved, it's an absolute blast, and anyone willing to put up with its shortcomings will likely have fun with the majority of the decently lengthy campaign.8 / 10, would play most of the missions again.

content:
, 2014
												Apparently I played this game about 124 hours to date and I think that's a wrong number. I figure I played the game 5 times that and maybe 10 times that. It's a great game. The eye candy is about as pleasant as can be for a PC that has limits on graphics power. It's a great game for single player action with the headphones on, on a rainy day outside and you're in the tropics, everything blue and sunny and your listening to jungle birds making nice sounds, waves lapping the beach and your looking for baddies. It's a classic. The enemy are not the smartest but they where never intended to be the smartest. This is a practice game, a learner, a reliable experience from beginning to end and you're going to love the scenery because it's nice to look at. The monsters are horrible and deserve no mercy and so it's easy fraging them and the enemy is a mix of fools, idiots and really bad nasty people. The vehicles are very good and the sound is very good. Make sure you can play it on the highest settings because this game looks very nice at the highest settings and that's when all the birds, little fish and insects com out. It's a classic and in the best of the best first person shooters of all time. There so many maps available for the game and there are map packs that are better than the game's original maps that are already excellent. You could buy this game, play out it's maps, install map packs and play it for years and never see the same map twice. A very good game with very good community support and it's very very stable with a PC built about 3-4 years after the game's release date. Around the game's release date the PCs had some issues with the game but that all changed when the PCs improved and software updates where released. The game is now solid. Buy it. You'll love it.

												Hold on, you're about tumble down into the abyss of negativity about how old this game is, just read this before you do. FarCry (the original, the classic, the brutal premier) is a somewhat dated but extremely satisfying experience. Unlike most titles, this game uses a combat engine similar to Counter Strike, in which every bullet won't be accurate if you're running or moving. In addition to ability to lean around corners, you also have a stamina bar and health doesn't regenerate. This classic example of fps  creativity was new, but is now nonexistent in MOST first-person games today. If you're looking for another positive aspect to this shooter (other than it's lush and vibrant graphics that still hold up on a polished engine) then look no further, for there is a level editor buried in the Bin folder, and it is exactly the same as the other FarCry editors. Is this game worth your time and cash? Definitely, pick it up, play it, and try to imagine this year is 2004.

												Though not the deepest of experiences, and still quite a tall order on even a modern non-gaming PC, Far Cry is still pretty fun. But be warned-- behind the reassuring veneer of campy-as-hell voice acting and action setpiece-packed first hour or so, this game is pretty hard, yo. The checkpoints are sparsely laid, and getting past every enemy camp is a twenty-minute ordeal of tagging all the enemies with the binoculars, taking out the snipers, waiting for someone to wander off alone, shooting them, moving to a new hiding spot, waiting for the heat to die down, and repeating. This is all because attempting anything other than the methodical stealthy approach will get you swiftly killed, because the player character's bullet resistance is vaguely realistic, and the enemies can see you from literally a mile away.Essentially, this is the poor man's version of Crysis, in which you have to take on a vast army in the jungle alone and without a superpowered nanosuit because you don't own a NASA supercomputer.

y 19, 2014
												Brutal, but fun!This is a terrific adventure through a tropical island filled with soldiers and Trigen and mutated Trigen soldiers, oh my! The way I played through it was by steal-nah, who am I kidding? I shot my way through everything in this game. Beware, the difficulty is very high, even on normal (the mode I played on). It is not so much that the AI is very attentive or breaks out of the basic mold games have for NPCs. No, the enemies can hit you from the furthest spots imaginable, and this can be quite a pain. However, it offers several checkpoints in its linear, but still open-world linear, levels. You are Jack Carver and you must make your way through an island filled with enemies out to kill you. Halfway through the game you find out that this is no normal island and scientific experiments are being conducted on...well, I won't spoil it, but it becomes more than what it seems at first. I would recommend playing through each level, taking a deep breath after you are done with one before moving on to the next level. This game offered quite a challenge and I can only imagine the difficulty it would have been had I played on the two higher modes...ugh! Overall, 8/10.

 Great Game From 2004 This game was my first game on PC, and remembered for me on whole life, I still play this game one time per year and still think that this is a great game, from graphic to very long gameplay in various environments, mostly in the jungle, but still have different gameplay in it. Trust me! Gameplay The first part of gameplay is shooting mercenaries exploring the location. Location in this game divided by levels, one level you play in one location (e.g. one part of the island), next level throw you on the next location (e.g. second part of the island), there is no open world. All location placed in the island. Second half of the game is mixed with mercenaries and "creatures" which can easily kill you if you relax in few seconds. The AI in this game is very hard, they perfectly see you by using their binocular-wall-hack eyes, and because of this, easy difficulty not so easy at all, you always get shot by a sniper from not loaded sniper tower or spotted by the enemy through a wall. Storyline It's have, but not so important, what important is stay alive. Score 10 Nostalgia / 10

												What this game is:a very hard, unforgiving, difficult, open world FPSsomewhere between STALKER and HL2a good teacher for your skills in patience and timingWhat this game is not:eyecandy (by todays standards)casualdid I mention this game is not easy?Gameplay:If you are new to this game, you will encounter a VERY steep learning curve. But once you mastered the correct use of binoculars and later heat vision, the game gets a lot easier; until the hard part of the game starts that is. I managed to finish this game on "Challenging", and that hopefully was the understatement of the year! I had to consult a walkthrough... IN A FPS!!! But do not get my wrong, the difficulty is not because of overwhelming odds or vile enemy placement, it is the AI.Overall, this is the game that "Phantom Commando" always deserved, and that's why it gets a solid thumbs up!

content:
r 14, 2012
												The ultimate example of how badly programmed AI can ruin a potentially decent game. When an enemy can spot you from the maximum view distance and have perfect aim with a machine gun, even through bushes and tent walls, you have a fundamentally broken game. What's even more laughable is that when you do briefly get an AI partner, that perfect aim disappears (though she was quite skilled at shooting me!).On top of that, the story, dialogue, and characters are all stupid and boring. If the tired botched-super-soldier-research plot wasn't cliched enough, they include a pointless scene where the only female character (who has a perfect body, naturally) bathes in her underwear. Oh, and spoiler alert: your male support character turns out to be evil.So, apart from a couple of interesting moments, and the pretty visuals, I can't recommend this. If you are foolish enough to buy this, take my advice: get a mod with a quicksave option.
