content:
2, 2014
												Well, yes and no. It can be good, but lots of other FPS games are better.It has a lot of good things; the open environment works surprisingly well, the many boats, cars and so on are a lot of fun and sniping and using googles is great. But it also has a lot of problems: First of all, the autosave is horrible, often I had to replay a lot I already had cleared a dozen times before I could get to the one point I had a problem with. We should just be allowed to save ourselves. Second, the zoom is very very old fashioned with all weapons lacking special scopes, like ordinary M4 machine guns. It looks horrible "zooming" with them. Thirdly, and possible most important, it indulge you to play stealth, sneaking around and so on, and most of the outdoor game looks like this was the way it was meant to play. BUT it is more or less impossible. Even on the easier levels the enemies are often simply impossible to sneak close to or around. When I got tired of trying about 20 times, I just front out assaulted a heavy defend fortress, and won. This I have tried several times in the game. It is far easier just going on a rampage up front killing everything than trying just to sneak around one enemy. Fourth, it is simply to long and, especially because of the lousy autosave, it really feels long. Fifth, it got lots of bugs. If you succed to sneak kill the enemies before they awaken their friends, there might happen a bug where the normal damage system no longer functions. For example, one place in the game, I sprayed a chopper with 8 missiles, nothing happened. Then I tried from the save point again, sprayed with 20 machine gun bullets just for the heck of it, and it blew up... Lots of other bugs also exist. And lastly, neither the plot, especially the anti-climatic ending, nor the gameplay is exciting enough to justify the long gameplay. It just become too much the same, to tedious. All in all, this game can be worth playing, but so are hundred of other games that I would advise you to prefer over this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2015
												Alright, no beating around the bush. This game is not quite as perfect as most of the reviews would have you believe. It definitely hasn't aged well. The first half(?) of the game before the monsters are revealed is entertaining and keeps your interest going. The wide, open levels are certainly well appreciated, as well as the graphics, which are still very appealing to this day. However, a lot of the alleged freedom is superficial with lots of wide, open areas having nothing whatsoever to justify exploring them, untraversable cliffs, and areas which misleadingly appear to lead somewhere (I know, poor sentence construction right there), but they end up being dead ends and the player ends up having to go all the way back. This is definitely not helped by painfully slow movement speed (think you can swim around the island to get to the objective? Think you can spare about 3 hours?) It boils down to the maps being inconsistently populated with the objective areas being heavilly populated with enemies and the rest of the space being "filler" with no weapon stashes, secrets or easter eggs to justify exploring them (another issue that Crysis inherited, though to a much lesser extent). The gunplay is pretty standard for the time. Most of the enemies are very bullet spongey and the only feasable option is to land a headshot (an issue, which CryTech did not amend in the spiritual sequel to Far Cry, Crysis), which ended up making most of the weapons feel pretty weak, the notable exception being the shotgun, which was just heavenly to use. Watching the enemies ragdoll around after finally taking them down is immensely satisfying. The enemies' bullet spongey nature would be fine if it weren't for the the way the entire game is designed. The difficulty is artificial, it is not fair, it is bullsh*t. The game heavilly encourages stealthy and/or slow paced approach to combat. The problem with that is that the ai isn't at all good enough nor are the stealth mechanics fleshed out enough to make stealth a feasable option. The AI will see you through brush, rock, and solid f*cking walls. Silenced weapons aren't worth sh*t. Silent takedowns? Ha! Just try, try to get close up to an enemy and not alert him. It's doable, I guess. With a lot of blood, sweat, and elbow grease you can get through certain areas without the f*cking Red Army on your tail. But is it fun? Not in the least. I don't get a smidge of enjoyment from sluggishly crawling past a group of mercs through bland, unpopulated brush. And no, it's not tense, it's not atmospheric, my heart isn't in my mouth when I'm trying to avoid getting spotted. It doesn't have that going for it.The best moments of the game where  dodging the amusingly slow-moving rockets of the big, lumbering mutants as three of them approached me, one charging me, while pumping shotguns into them and running loops around them. But don't expect to do a lot of that, because you are made of wet tissue paper. Besides the lumbering giants, all other enemies have rapid firing firearms and prestine aim. Good luck dodging or weaving your way through that sh*t (have I mentioned the movement speed is god awful slow?). The forced slow pacing is reinforced by very sparse ammo and health locations and an ever depleting stamina bar. Maybe, maybe the slow pacing would work if youthe player had regenerating health (yeah, I know: "CoD fanboy, go back to your Medal of Modern Battlefield 4!" Bite me), but instead you find yourself grinding through encounter after encounter, while incurring unavoidable damage, and finally having to face a roomful of enemies with some 2% health or whatnot.SynopsisWell... that's a lot of negativity. Never the less, there is fun to be had in this game. Despite the often time empty and pointless areas, the levels' large scale and detail is very appealing, esp. the first level they packed everything into that level. Any B-movie enthusiast will adore the voice acting and plot, despite their bullet-spongey nature a lot of the enemy design is cool (shout out to invis-guy and proto-Berserkers (disclaimer: not a big fan of GoW)), and the basal gunplay is appealing. The game's biggest problems stem from the open ended level design and forced slow pace. I can only recommend it to the most patient of gamers. To the curious casual I recommend entering a couple cheats (if this game has cheats, I know the Xbox version has cheats) and playing through it on the lowest difficulty. One should approach this as one would approach a B-movie, not a timeless classic. I would certainly recommend (the first half of) Crysis or the X-Box spin off series over this one, seeing as the stealth, gunplay, and movement are much more solid in those games.More disclaimer: (Have not touched the multiplayer, and this is my first review on Steam, which I just sort of winged right now w/o really thinking it through.)

												Fixed the bugs in 1.4 via a patch and instructions I got online.WARNING: I might reveal some parts of the game's plot, so if you want the full experience and not spoil the game's brilliant plot for yourself, look away.So, main point: I have this game as the CD version as I bought it way back in 2005. I had so much fun playing it and getting stuck at levels like Boat (Crowe was incredibly hard to fend off) and Volcano (♥♥♥♥ing fat boy Trigens) were frustrating, but it made a young 9-year-old me incredibly focused because the Trigens terrified the ♥♥♥♥ out of me and mercs were deadly accurate. I have played and beaten the game countless times and tried to complete the Carrier level (if you have played the game you'll know that this level can be beaten with relative ease) in record time, and I never tire of shooting that traitor Doyle at the end. Overall if you want a real classic and something cheap to while away your time with, I highly recommend that you buy this game. Not an open world like it's predecessors now, but you should still explore as the game devs have hidden some Easter Eggs in certain levels. And if you're not too demanding and ♥♥♥♥♥y on graphics, then this game will do wonders for you. Just remember to have a Shotgun on hand whenever you're in a level with Trigens.

content:
2, 2015
												Great Game, looks fantastic for its age. Oddly enough, in most games the cutscenes look better than the actual game, here it is th eopposite, the cutscenes are a bit clunky and jarring, but still have their charm. The Missions are wide open so there are plenty of routes to take to get to the end, especially the missions with multiple islands. This is cool, especially when you can choose to be stealthy, snipe your opponents, or just run in guns a-blazing!The game is pretty challenging even on the lower difficulties. You will have to replay certains parts over and over again, until you finally learn all the enemy patterns and placement, and can do the section near-flawlessly. Checkpoint system is really good with multiple checkpoints per level, however certain checkpoints are a bit too far apart. Driving is a bit clunky, but there is something about first-erson driving in these types of games, that I just love. Finally the last few levels will most likely make you pull your hair out in frustration, I think they could have provided a bit more health and armor packs.All in all great, classic FPS Adventure!

content:
2, 2014
												Well, yes and no. It can be good, but lots of other FPS games are better.It has a lot of good things; the open environment works surprisingly well, the many boats, cars and so on are a lot of fun and sniping and using googles is great. But it also has a lot of problems: First of all, the autosave is horrible, often I had to replay a lot I already had cleared a dozen times before I could get to the one point I had a problem with. We should just be allowed to save ourselves. Second, the zoom is very very old fashioned with all weapons lacking special scopes, like ordinary M4 machine guns. It looks horrible "zooming" with them. Thirdly, and possible most important, it indulge you to play stealth, sneaking around and so on, and most of the outdoor game looks like this was the way it was meant to play. BUT it is more or less impossible. Even on the easier levels the enemies are often simply impossible to sneak close to or around. When I got tired of trying about 20 times, I just front out assaulted a heavy defend fortress, and won. This I have tried several times in the game. It is far easier just going on a rampage up front killing everything than trying just to sneak around one enemy. Fourth, it is simply to long and, especially because of the lousy autosave, it really feels long. Fifth, it got lots of bugs. If you succed to sneak kill the enemies before they awaken their friends, there might happen a bug where the normal damage system no longer functions. For example, one place in the game, I sprayed a chopper with 8 missiles, nothing happened. Then I tried from the save point again, sprayed with 20 machine gun bullets just for the heck of it, and it blew up... Lots of other bugs also exist. And lastly, neither the plot, especially the anti-climatic ending, nor the gameplay is exciting enough to justify the long gameplay. It just become too much the same, to tedious. All in all, this game can be worth playing, but so are hundred of other games that I would advise you to prefer over this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2015
												Alright, no beating around the bush. This game is not quite as perfect as most of the reviews would have you believe. It definitely hasn't aged well. The first half(?) of the game before the monsters are revealed is entertaining and keeps your interest going. The wide, open levels are certainly well appreciated, as well as the graphics, which are still very appealing to this day. However, a lot of the alleged freedom is superficial with lots of wide, open areas having nothing whatsoever to justify exploring them, untraversable cliffs, and areas which misleadingly appear to lead somewhere (I know, poor sentence construction right there), but they end up being dead ends and the player ends up having to go all the way back. This is definitely not helped by painfully slow movement speed (think you can swim around the island to get to the objective? Think you can spare about 3 hours?) It boils down to the maps being inconsistently populated with the objective areas being heavilly populated with enemies and the rest of the space being "filler" with no weapon stashes, secrets or easter eggs to justify exploring them (another issue that Crysis inherited, though to a much lesser extent). The gunplay is pretty standard for the time. Most of the enemies are very bullet spongey and the only feasable option is to land a headshot (an issue, which CryTech did not amend in the spiritual sequel to Far Cry, Crysis), which ended up making most of the weapons feel pretty weak, the notable exception being the shotgun, which was just heavenly to use. Watching the enemies ragdoll around after finally taking them down is immensely satisfying. The enemies' bullet spongey nature would be fine if it weren't for the the way the entire game is designed. The difficulty is artificial, it is not fair, it is bullsh*t. The game heavilly encourages stealthy and/or slow paced approach to combat. The problem with that is that the ai isn't at all good enough nor are the stealth mechanics fleshed out enough to make stealth a feasable option. The AI will see you through brush, rock, and solid f*cking walls. Silenced weapons aren't worth sh*t. Silent takedowns? Ha! Just try, try to get close up to an enemy and not alert him. It's doable, I guess. With a lot of blood, sweat, and elbow grease you can get through certain areas without the f*cking Red Army on your tail. But is it fun? Not in the least. I don't get a smidge of enjoyment from sluggishly crawling past a group of mercs through bland, unpopulated brush. And no, it's not tense, it's not atmospheric, my heart isn't in my mouth when I'm trying to avoid getting spotted. It doesn't have that going for it.The best moments of the game where  dodging the amusingly slow-moving rockets of the big, lumbering mutants as three of them approached me, one charging me, while pumping shotguns into them and running loops around them. But don't expect to do a lot of that, because you are made of wet tissue paper. Besides the lumbering giants, all other enemies have rapid firing firearms and prestine aim. Good luck dodging or weaving your way through that sh*t (have I mentioned the movement speed is god awful slow?). The forced slow pacing is reinforced by very sparse ammo and health locations and an ever depleting stamina bar. Maybe, maybe the slow pacing would work if youthe player had regenerating health (yeah, I know: "CoD fanboy, go back to your Medal of Modern Battlefield 4!" Bite me), but instead you find yourself grinding through encounter after encounter, while incurring unavoidable damage, and finally having to face a roomful of enemies with some 2% health or whatnot.SynopsisWell... that's a lot of negativity. Never the less, there is fun to be had in this game. Despite the often time empty and pointless areas, the levels' large scale and detail is very appealing, esp. the first level they packed everything into that level. Any B-movie enthusiast will adore the voice acting and plot, despite their bullet-spongey nature a lot of the enemy design is cool (shout out to invis-guy and proto-Berserkers (disclaimer: not a big fan of GoW)), and the basal gunplay is appealing. The game's biggest problems stem from the open ended level design and forced slow pace. I can only recommend it to the most patient of gamers. To the curious casual I recommend entering a couple cheats (if this game has cheats, I know the Xbox version has cheats) and playing through it on the lowest difficulty. One should approach this as one would approach a B-movie, not a timeless classic. I would certainly recommend (the first half of) Crysis or the X-Box spin off series over this one, seeing as the stealth, gunplay, and movement are much more solid in those games.More disclaimer: (Have not touched the multiplayer, and this is my first review on Steam, which I just sort of winged right now w/o really thinking it through.)

												I rate the game Far Cry 2.5/5. Not Good. Not even okay.This was probably one of the most graphically beautiful games of its time (Unreal Tournament 2004 is more beautiful by far however) and features fairly good AI and fairly large areas (but not as large as those in UT 2004). However it features a generic story filled with bad dialogue, worse voice acting and features cutscenes needlessly focusing on computer generated T&A throughout. To make matters worse this game is extremely hard, even on the easiest difficulty level and the checkpoint-based save system makes things even harder. (This game was so difficult I had to resort to using a left-over developer debug mode to make my character invincible so I could get through this game at all). This high difficulty results in high frustration and while many of the gameplay areas and levels are fairly big, this doesn't prevent them from being designed in an extremely linear manner. Many of the outdoor areas found in this game were re-used in the far more open-ended and excellently designed Far Cry 3 game.

er 28, 2014
												Awful cheesy writing. Good Controls...impossible scenarios. Kind of like the action movies we all loved from the 80s, in video game form. But impossibly long...everytime I thought it was going to be over or near the end it just keeps going. In some ways i'd like to consider that high value, but I guess for me I prefer my FPS games a bit shorter. One other complaint that I am sure is included in most other reviews, is there is a terrible glitch that causes the enemy to easily target and shoot you through walls in some areas, as if the wall isn't even there. This can get very annoying at times. But thankfully it only occurs in certain places, and you can adapt your strategy to work around this problem.I suspect when it came out this game introduced a lot of new concepts to the FPS genre, and even by todays standards it isn't a terrible game. However I don't know that playing it is really necessary unless you're hardcore and want to play every FPS or every Far Cry game in the series. Final Verdict: Not amazing by today's standards (obviously as it has been around for at least a decade). I wouldn't recommend for the casual FPS player like myself. However for those looking for older style FPS game play with higher difficulty which requires a bit of strategy and guerrilla tactics, and a lack of gimmicks that make the game easier (like slow-mo in F.E.A.R.) this game is still pretty solid.2004 Rating: 9/10 (1 point off for the cheesy scenes with Val)2014 Rating: 7/10

content:
27, 2011
												Far Cry was a real game-changer in the FPS genre. In fact, it still holds up pretty well. The dialogue and voice acting are cartoonishly bad, but the ability to engage enemies on your own terms was and still is VERY refreshing. You can run in guns blazing, snipe targets from a distance, create distractions to draw people away, or even sneak past most places. There are a lot of guns, and the inventory restrictions ensure you don't get too complacent with any one weapon.The visuals obviously haven't aged well, but they still have an old charm to them. Add to that a dynamic soundtrack composed by Inon Zur and some strategc level design and Far Cry is an aesthetically pleasing package. The plot kind of drags on, especially in the later chapters, but the philosophy of open combat areas and multiple ways to approach them hardly ever slows down. Not to mention, vehicles are a blast to drive.So, who is Far Cry for? I guess in a nutshell, it's for anybody looking for a unique and still largely-untouched style of FPS and doesn't need super-clear objectives or an engrossing/serious story. It's for anybody who is seriously interested in the history of the FPS genre. I'd put it up there with the likes of DOOM, Half-Life, and BioShock. Despite being 10 years old, it's aged gracefully and it never tries to take itself too seriously. Absolutely a must-buy.

content:
17, 2015
												Well, it's a good old fashioned, hardcore shooter, but technologically advanced with sometimes fun conversations. It's nice to see where the Far Cry as we know nowdays, came from. But when the first sucka jumped into my face and killed me with one hit, I immediately remembered why I never ever tried this earlier. When the game turned into Doom, I instantly started to hate it. The story is terrible, the combat system not so smooth and the difficult is kinda broken, for about to the half of the game its seems like match to the choosen difficulty, but after that its rapidly grow into hard than impossible. ( Cause I don't like to abandon games I started, i had to use cheat mode to run trough the rest :( )Old school gamers probably still will love it, but if you tried one of the newer episodes first, don't go back to this one.5/10

content:
11, 2015
												So I decided to buy a Far Cry bundle on sale and started with the first game. Now I'm not a newb to stealth games - but this game is bloody ridiculous. The AI has been poorly - and I emphasise the POORLY coded. They see and hear you irrelevant of your location (distance/terrain) - it is pretty much impossible to execute a stealth kill without setting an entire base off on high alert, who omnipotently know exactly where you are and can shoot through trees at you.After playing the first section several times over & dying a lot I decided the game was a pile of poop - regaling my distaste to friends. Who then pointed out that no one should ever play Far Cry (the first game) and anyone who wants to get into the franchise should ignore that it exists.Good advice!

content:
y 3, 2013
												This game has terrible voice acting, a sub-par storyline, and infuriating gameplay at times, and yet I find myself wanting to triumph over it all the more. This is an excellent game if you like a challenge or are a masochist. If you think you find yourself replaying the same segment repeatedly early on, just wait until about halfway through the game when the enemies that are capable of jumping across the map and slashing at your face to kill you in two hits even though you have a full set of armor and are completely healthy are given rocket launchers. Were you having fun progressing the story line? Too bad, you're going to be there for at least three hours popping blood vessels in your head from all of your irritatingly failed attempts at making it to the next checkpoint just so you don't have to complete the segment a seventy sixth time. I never considered myself a decent gamer, by any means, but I have never had this much trouble getting through a game on the normal difficulty. It is the most unforgiving gameplay I have ever subject myself to and yet each small accomplishment makes you strive for more. It is difficult, but not impossible. It feels very rewarding to complete and I would recommend it to anyone looking for something difficult. I wouldn't necessarily if it weren't so cheap, but as it stands, I'd say it's worth it.

content:
10, 2015
												Ah, back to the days when FPS games were designed around a single player campaign. This game has a single player that just. keeps. going. It just gets tiresome after a while, and the last two or three levels are insanely difficult. Also checkpoint-based autosave and no manual saving means a lot re-playing content every time you die.One last thing: this game is definitely NOT open world. It's a chapter-based, linear storyline.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
5, 2015
												FarCry is a beautifully presented, charming, organic FPS that will serve as a great use of one's time and money, though that time will be marred by some minor errors.FarCry's mechanics are based around limited weapon slots, health management and stealth (though some missions will evolve into full on shootouts after a nice build up) with a plethora of enemies, enemy types and level designs ranging from expansive tropical locations to claustrophobic labs straight out of cheesy Sci-Fi dreams infested with Doom 3 looking monsters called Trigens. The game is incredibly long for newcomers but it's organic enough to allow people who are used to it to rush through levels should they know the best ways to get around the levels (hence my 6 hour playthrough as of writing this review, haven finished it a few hours ago). It also does well in terms of loading, with a loading screen only occuring at the start of each mission, and if you load a save and modern PCs shouldn't have issues with long load times like many did back in 2004.However a lot of FarCry requires attrition and getting used to. The Steam version has some levels fail and cause the occasional enemy to see you through walls, though it's still much preferrable to the new Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 port in terms of the stealth. The Trigens and the Mercanaries do insane amounts of damage with their weapons, and you'll have to make careful use of your binoculars to catch the occasional Sniper or Rocket Sniper. The vehicle sections are crap and are best used very quickly and abandoned to hide once you reach your destination.On the whole, however, it's an above average game marred by the occasional slip up in AI and balancing, but held up by the scope and the charm of the cheesy story and aesthetic, as well as the catharsis of the gameplay. FarCry is my favourite game, and I'm happy to say that the Steam version is about as good as the disc version from 2004, and better than 2014's console versions.
